segment.source: Lab 1e: Add a driver to an image
segment.target: Lab 1e: Add a driver to an image

segment.source: Lab 1e: Add a driver to an image
segment.target: Lab 1e: Add a driver to an image

segment.source: Now we'll add drivers to a Windows 10 IoT Core image.
segment.target: Now we'll add drivers to a Windows 10 IoT Core image.

segment.source: When you're using a pre-built Board Support Package (BSP), you'll want to know whether there's already similar drivers on the board.
segment.target: When you're using a pre-built Board Support Package (BSP), you'll want to know whether there's already similar drivers on the board.

segment.source: If not, you can usually just add the new driver.
segment.target: If not, you can usually just add the new driver.

segment.source: If there is, but that driver doesn't meet your needs, then you'll need to replace the driver from the BSP, which we'll cover in Lab 2a.
segment.target: If there is, but that driver doesn't meet your needs, then you'll need to replace the driver from the BSP, which we'll cover in Lab 2a.

segment.source: In our lab, we'll use the sample driver: Hello, Blinky!, package it up, and deploy it to the device.
segment.target: In our lab, we'll use the sample driver: Hello, Blinky!, package it up, and deploy it to the device.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: Complete Lab 1a: Create a basic image.
segment.target: Complete Lab 1a: Create a basic image.

segment.source: Create your test files
segment.target: Create your test files

segment.source: Complete the exercises in Installing The Sample Driver to build the Hello, Blinky app.
segment.target: Complete the exercises in Installing The Sample Driver to build the Hello, Blinky app.

segment.source: You'll create three files: ACPITABL.dat, gpiokmdfdemo.inf, and gpiokmdfdemo.sys, which you'll use to install the driver.
segment.target: You'll create three files: ACPITABL.dat, gpiokmdfdemo.inf, and gpiokmdfdemo.sys, which you'll use to install the driver.

segment.source: You can also use your own IoT Core driver, so long as it doesn't conflict with the existing Board Support Package (BSP).
segment.target: You can also use your own IoT Core driver, so long as it doesn't conflict with the existing Board Support Package (BSP).

segment.source: Copy each of the files: gpiokmdfdemo.sys, gpiokmdfdemo.inf, and ACPITABL.dat into a test folder, for example, C:\gpiokmdfdemo
segment.target: Copy each of the files: gpiokmdfdemo.sys, gpiokmdfdemo.inf, and ACPITABL.dat into a test folder, for example, C:\gpiokmdfdemo

segment.source: Build a package for your driver
segment.target: Build a package for your driver

segment.source: Run C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitToolsIoTCoreShell as an administrator.
segment.target: Run C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitToolsIoTCoreShell as an administrator.

segment.source: Create the driver package using the .inf file as the base:
segment.target: Create the driver package using the .inf file as the base:

segment.source: The new folder at C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-archPackagesDrivers.HelloBlinky.
segment.target: The new folder at C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-archPackagesDrivers.HelloBlinky.

segment.source: Verify that the sample files are in the package
segment.target: Verify that the sample files are in the package

segment.source: Update the driver's package definition file, C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-archPackagesDrivers.HelloBlinkyDrivers.HelloBlinky.pkg.xml.
segment.target: Update the driver's package definition file, C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-archPackagesDrivers.HelloBlinkyDrivers.HelloBlinky.pkg.xml.

segment.source: The default package definition file includes sample XML that you can modify to add your own driver files.
segment.target: The default package definition file includes sample XML that you can modify to add your own driver files.

segment.source: If necessary, update the value of File Source to point to your .SYS file, and the ACPITABL.dat file.
segment.target: If necessary, update the value of File Source to point to your .SYS file, and the ACPITABL.dat file.

segment.source: (You don't need to add the .INF file.) Add the DestinationDir of "$(runtime.drivers)".
segment.target: (You don't need to add the .INF file.) Add the DestinationDir of "$(runtime.drivers)".

segment.source: From the IoT Core Shell, build the package.
segment.target: From the IoT Core Shell, build the package.

segment.source: The package is built, appearing as C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitBuildarchpkgsyour OEM name.Drivers.HelloBlinky.cab.
segment.target: The package is built, appearing as C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitBuildarchpkgsyour OEM name.Drivers.HelloBlinky.cab.

segment.source: Update your feature manifest
segment.target: Update your feature manifest

segment.source: Add your driver package to the feature manifest
segment.target: Add your driver package to the feature manifest

segment.source: Open the architecture-specific feature manifest file, C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-PackagesOEMFM.xml
segment.target: Open the architecture-specific feature manifest file, C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-PackagesOEMFM.xml

segment.source: Create a new PackageFile section in the XML, with your package file listed, and give it a new FeatureID, such as "OEMDriverHelloBlinky".
segment.target: Create a new PackageFile section in the XML, with your package file listed, and give it a new FeatureID, such as "OEMDriverHelloBlinky".

segment.source: You'll now be able to add your driver to your product by adding a reference to this feature manifest.
segment.target: You'll now be able to add your driver to your product by adding a reference to this feature manifest.

segment.source: Update the project's configuration files
segment.target: Update the project's configuration files

segment.source: Open your product's test configuration file: C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-armProductsProductATestOEMInput.xml.
segment.target: Open your product's test configuration file: C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-armProductsProductATestOEMInput.xml.

segment.source: Make sure your feature manifest, OEMFM.xml, is in the list of AdditionalFMs.
segment.target: Make sure your feature manifest, OEMFM.xml, is in the list of AdditionalFMs.

segment.source: Add it if it isn't there already there:
segment.target: Add it if it isn't there already there:

segment.source: Add the FeatureID for your driver:
segment.target: Add the FeatureID for your driver:

segment.source: Build and test the image
segment.target: Build and test the image

segment.source: Build the image
segment.target: Build the image

segment.source: From the IoT Core Shell, create the image:
segment.target: From the IoT Core Shell, create the image:

segment.source: This creates the product binaries at C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitBuildarchProductAFlash.FFU.
segment.target: This creates the product binaries at C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitBuildarchProductAFlash.FFU.

segment.source: Start Windows IoT Core DashboardSetup a new deviceCustom, and browse to your image.
segment.target: Start Windows IoT Core DashboardSetup a new deviceCustom, and browse to your image.

segment.source: Put the Micro SD card in the device, select it, accept the license terms, and click Install.
segment.target: Put the Micro SD card in the device, select it, accept the license terms, and click Install.

segment.source: This replaces the previous image with our new image.
segment.target: This replaces the previous image with our new image.

segment.source: Put the card into the IoT device and start it up.
segment.target: Put the card into the IoT device and start it up.

segment.source: After a short while, the device should start automatically, and you should see your app.
segment.target: After a short while, the device should start automatically, and you should see your app.

segment.source: Check to see if your driver works
segment.target: Check to see if your driver works

segment.source: Use the procedures in the Hello, Blinky! lab to test your driver.
segment.target: Use the procedures in the Hello, Blinky! lab to test your driver.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: Lab 2a: Replace a driver in an existing board support package
segment.target: Lab 2a: Replace a driver in an existing board support package
